text:
When writing software to deal with data that is bigger than memory (30gb+ - 200gb) is the standard to rely on virtual memory (assuming a good preforming SSD) or process the data in chunks then merge at the end?

I’m assuming there’s multiple opinions on this topic. I couldn’t find much information online.

Heres how I see it from my opinion, please correct me if Im wrong.

Virtual memory:
• Easier to implement
• Great when additional memory needed is not too big
• Hardware dependent
• Doesn’t preform well on really big data?
• Not possible on docker??
Chunking:
• More lines of code, more things can go wrong.
• Not as hardware dependent
• Preforms better on really big data?

text: Docker supports swap, but lots of container orchestration systems (most notably, Kubernetes) do not (and not all Linux installations have swap enabled).

text: Using mkswap in linux on nvme disks works pretty ok. I do not have any benchmarks but it is easy to setup and just run. RAM is pretty cheap nowadays too, a 64GB stick is like 300 USD.

text:
You should also consider memory mapping.
It's kind of the complement to Swap.
In swap the OS puts onto disk memory it doesn't think you will want.
In memory mapping the OS pulls into RAM memory it thinks you are about to want 

- requires careful choice of data types  to be possible
 - faster than normal `read`
 - OS has better heuristics that let it preemptively load (or so I am told)
